source.e246aae8:
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import os
source.bbd1e6e3:
# Read data into this notebook
data = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/omicron-covid19-variant-daily-cases/covid-variants.csv')

# Change date column into datetime object
data.date = pd.to_datetime(data.date)
data.head()
source.a25c7f47:
temp_data = data.groupby(by='date')['num_sequences_total'].sum()
fig = px.bar(temp_data, x=temp_data.index, y=temp_data, color=temp_data)
fig.update_layout(title='How sequences look like around the world?',
                 xaxis=dict(title='Date', showgrid=False),
                 yaxis=dict(title='Number of Case', showgrid=False),
                 )
fig.show()
source.4004301a:
fig = px.sunburst(data, path=['location'], values='num_sequences_total', title='Number of case for each country')
fig.show()
source.0e94cce4:
# Plot total number of case for each year 
for year in data.date.dt.year.unique():
    temp_data = data[data.date.dt.year == year]
    fig = px.treemap(temp_data, path=['location'], values='num_sequences_total', title=f"Number of Case in {year}")
    fig.show()
source.bb42a332:
variant_sum = data.groupby('variant')['num_sequences'].sum()
fig = px.sunburst(variant_sum, path=[variant_sum.index], values=variant_sum,
                 title='Number of sequences for each variant')
fig.show()
source.c009c130: This may be because there is not enough data in 2022. However, let's look at which variant has the highest num sequences(number of case).
